conclusion: The cylinder is divided into two chambers, each with volume V, pressure p, and temperature T; diaphragm has mass m and rests on a ledge.
The diaphragm is in equilibrium under gravity and pressure difference; force due to gravity is mg; pressure difference must balance this force.
Pressure difference is p1 - p2 = mg/A, where A is the cross-sectional area of the cylinder.
Total volume of the cylinder is 2V; V0 is the volume of the lower chamber when gas starts to leak; upper chamber volume is 2V - V0.
For the lower chamber, p1 V0 = n1 RT; for the upper chamber, p2 (2V - V0) = n2 RT; assume n1 = n2 = n.
From ideal gas law, p1 = nRT/V0 and p2 = nRT/(2V - V0); substitute into pressure difference equation.
Factor out nRT: nRT (1/V0 - 1/(2V - V0)) = mg/A; combine fractions: nRT (2V - 2V0)/(V0 (2V - V0)) = mg/A.
Rearrange equation: 2nRT(V - V0)/(V0 (2V - V0)) = mg/A; multiply both sides by V0 (2V - V0).
Let x = mgH/pV; note H = V/A, so x = mg/(pA).
Substitute x into equation: V - V0 = x V0 (2V - V0); expand and rearrange: xV0^2 - (2xV + 1)V0 + V = 0.
Quadratic equation in V0: xV0^2 - (2xV + 1)V0 + V = 0; solve using quadratic formula.
